Description: Rim and body sherd of Chian pottery Type B1 kantharos with handle root preserved at top of rim; white slip; interior: glazed streaky black with lotus bud in added white outline with added red centre above red and white bands; exterior reserved; inscription on exterior.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Naukratis) (according to Ashmolean Museum register)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd joins British Museum 1924,1201.840. Kantharoi Type B1 have lotus flowers and lotus buds on the interior (Williams 1983, 169). Many kantharoi Type B have painted inscriptions beneath the rim and several have been found on Aegina as well as at Naukratis. The fabric of the sherd was analysed by the Research Laboratory for Archaeology at Oxford. Using Ward's Method Cluster Analysis (WMCA) and Principal Components Analysis (PCA), the fabric was found to have originated in the Kampos plain in the east of the island of Chios (Jones 1986, p.286). It must also be pointed out that despite Jones' identification of the sherd as being in the Chalice Style, the sherd firmly belongs to a Type B kantharos. Williams, D. ‘Aigina, Aphaia-Tempel 5. The pottery from Chios’, Archäologischer Anzeiger 1983.
Bibliographic references: Cook & Woodhead 1952 / Painted Inscriptions on Chiot Pottery (p. 169, no. 188)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 735, no. 957)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 82, no. 21, pl. V)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1882) (phase 2)

Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
